newsitem.title: CANADA: Falconbridge union sees progress in talks.
newsitem.headline: Falconbridge union sees progress in talks.

text.p: Contract talks between Falconbridge Ltd and the nickel miner's Sudbury workers made significant progress over the weekend, union officials said on Monday.
Negotiations between Falconbridge and the union resumed Friday night after breaking down last Wednesday.

"We've been bargaining throughout the weekend. There has been significant movement on both parties' side. We're going to continue bargaining through the week," Canadian Auto Workers union spokesman Rolly Gauthier said in a telephone interview.
The talks are still focused on non-monetary issues such as contract language, pensions and job security, Gauthier said.
Earlier this month, Falconbridge's 1,400 unionized mine workers in Sudbury voted 91.28 percent in favor of giving their negotiating team a strike mandate.
The current contract expires August 1. Gauthier said the chances of avoiding a strike had improved over the weekend.
"Last week I was saying (the odds) were 9 out of 10 for a possible strike. I've downgraded that to 7 out of 10," he said.
Falconbridge's Sudbury operations produced 42,100 tonnes of nickel, 48,800 tonnes of copper and 730 tonnes of cobalt last year.
